title: 113_hr955
content: The Act is titled the "Hadiya Pendleton and Nyasia Pryear-Yard Stop Illegal Trafficking in Firearms Act of 2013" and includes various amendments related to anti-straw purchasing and firearms trafficking. The "Hadiya Pendleton and Nyasia Pryear-Yard Stop Illegal Trafficking in Firearms Act of 2013" adds a new section to Chapter 44 of title 18, United States Code, prohibiting straw purchasing of firearms. It defines terms like "crime of violence" and "drug trafficking crime" and makes it illegal for anyone other than licensed individuals to knowingly purchase firearms in interstate or foreign commerce. The "Hadiya Pendleton and Nyasia Pryear-Yard Stop Illegal Trafficking in Firearms Act of 2013" prohibits the purchase of firearms in interstate or foreign commerce by individuals who are not licensed, if they know or have reasonable cause to believe that the recipient is involved in criminal activities or is a fugitive from justice. The "Hadiya Pendleton and Nyasia Pryear-Yard Stop Illegal Trafficking in Firearms Act of 2013" prohibits the purchase of firearms by individuals who are not licensed if they fall under specific criteria such as being a controlled substance user, mentally defective, illegal alien, dishonorably discharged from the Armed Forces, or a former citizen of the United States. The text chunk discusses individuals who have renounced their U.S. citizenship or are subject to a court order restraining them from harassing or threatening their intimate partner or child. The court order must have been issued after a hearing where the person had notice and the opportunity to participate. The text chunk outlines criteria for individuals prohibited from possessing firearms, including those convicted of domestic violence misdemeanors and those intending to use firearms in violent or criminal activities. The text chunk outlines penalties for individuals violating firearm possession laws, including fines, imprisonment up to 15 years, or up to 25 years if the firearm is believed to be used in a violent crime. It also exempts lawfully purchased firearms from certain restrictions. The text chunk discusses the lawful gifting of firearms to recipients who have not provided any service or value in exchange, as well as gifting to winners of raffles, contests, or auctions. It is unlawful to transfer 2 or more firearms to another person if the transferor knows or believes the recipient would violate federal law. Similarly, receiving 2 or more firearms is illegal if the recipient knows or believes it would result in a violation of federal law. Any person who violates subsection (a) of the law shall face fines, imprisonment up to 15 years, or both. If the violation involves coordination with 5 or more individuals in a leadership role, the sentence can be up to 25 years. Convicted individuals must forfeit any proceeds obtained from the violation to the United States. The court must order forfeiture of all property used in committing the violation. Defendants profiting from the offense may face fines up to twice the gross profits. Amendments to Title III of the United States Code are made regarding the authorization. The United States Code is amended to include sections 932 and 933 related to firearms trafficking and straw purchasing. The Sentencing Commission is directed to review and amend guidelines for these offenses. The Sentencing Commission is directed to review and amend guidelines for offenses related to firearms trafficking and straw purchasing, with increased penalties for those affiliated with criminal enterprises. Amendments to the United States Code include sections 932 and 933 for these offenses. Amendments to Section 922(D) include provisions related to straw purchasing of firearms, trafficking in firearms, and forfeiture and fines. Amendments to Section 922(d) of title 18, United States Code, include new provisions regarding the sale or disposal of firearms or ammunition to specific individuals or for criminal purposes. This subsection does not apply to licensed importers, manufacturers, dealers, or collectors. The subsection exempts licensed importers, manufacturers, dealers, or collectors from restrictions on selling firearms or ammunition to certain individuals. Amendments to sections 924(a) and 924(h) of title 18, United States Code, impose fines and imprisonment for knowingly violating certain subsections related to firearms. Amendment to section 924 of title 18, United States Code, increases penalties for knowingly receiving or transferring firearms or ammunition for use in violent crimes, drug trafficking, or other specified offenses, with a maximum imprisonment of 25 years. The amendment to section 924 of title 18, United States Code, increases penalties for receiving or transferring firearms for use in violent crimes, drug trafficking, or other specified offenses, with a maximum imprisonment of 25 years. This subsection shall run concurrently with any term of imprisonment imposed on the person under section 932. AMENDMENTS TO SECTION 924(K) increase penalties for receiving or transferring firearms for violent crimes, drug trafficking, or specified offenses, with a maximum imprisonment of 25 years. Section 924 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to increase penalties for smuggling firearms or ammunition into the United States with intent to engage in illegal activities, punishable under various laws, including drug trafficking and crimes of violence. Offenders face up to 15 years in prison, fines, or both. A person who smuggles or takes out of the United States a firearm or ammunition with intent to engage in illegal activities punishable under certain laws, faces up to 15 years in prison, fines, or both.
